Um, but I, I suppose by thinking that it‚Äôs very, very scalable and it can hold a lot, I would suggest there, there probably is still a limit to how much it can hold you, you like, how would it scale? One way it could scale is that it, um, it, it starts to delay tasks longer and longer so that you don‚Äôt get the, you know, you, you could imagine it scaling in that way, right?

Because if like a thousand became 10,000, it‚Äôs just that you, that, that,

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: see each of them less frequently, but that‚Äôs not necessarily acceptable. Right. So, so it still has a scaling problem, I would say. And so the piece that I‚Äôd want to make sure was built into it somehow was this idea of deleting, closing, you know, getting rid of things that actually don‚Äôt matter anymore, but maybe you think that just happens automatically.

Like obviously if something really doesn‚Äôt matter, we‚Äôre gonna get rid of it anyway. So it doesn‚Äôt really need to, it doesn‚Äôt need an extra solution because I do already do it,

Tristram: Yes. Yeah. That, that, that‚Äôs, that is, that is the workflow. Like one, after I‚Äôve done something, let‚Äôs say the fleeting note is, is like a, an interesting turn of phrase that I think might work really well in one of my podcasts that I‚Äôm writing. I will just copy it, put it into the, the podcast note and delete the fleeting note.

Then I‚Äôll never see it ever again.

Robin: no, of course. You would delete fleeting notes. I just meant, um, it‚Äôs the action of like having a brain fart one day and being like, well, what about this? Throw it into the system tomorrow [00:40:00] or next week. It comes back up and I‚Äôm like, actually, you know what, I‚Äôm realistically never gonna do that. Get rid of it.

And it‚Äôs that, it‚Äôs that, that I‚Äôd like to reinforce. ‚Äôcause I think there is a lot of value in, uh, it‚Äôs, it‚Äôs like, yeah, it‚Äôs, it‚Äôs a yny philosophy. That‚Äôs not exactly what Yny means because Yny is about building software. But it, but to me it‚Äôs important for the same

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: right? Like you could build an infinitely complex software system.

You don‚Äôt do that because that‚Äôs terrible engineering and it‚Äôll probably never be released. So you design it or you don‚Äôt undersign it, but you design it right down to the basics in an.

Tristram: Okay. Well, I mean the

Robin: System. I, I‚Äôm loving the sound of, I particularly love the sound of, um, uh, yeah, like being able to snooze without thinking when like it‚Äôs really annoying to have to like decide when.

Tristram: yes, it, the problem, the, one of the problems that Zettelkasten solves is. Uh, in a separate, a separate, a separate problem that Zeen solves is when you‚Äôre taking a note, you shouldn‚Äôt have to think hard about where it goes when you‚Äôre just writing something down on the back of an envelope or you‚Äôre just quickly putting something in.

Any friction is bad friction. Like you‚Äôre just gonna get that out of your brain on there and then forget about it because you trust the system to bring it back at the correct point, which for me are these morning, these morning reviews. And that‚Äôs, that‚Äôs what this does. Um, ze is a bottom up, bottom.

Excuse me. Zein is a bottom up system where instead of saying, okay, like in Dewey Decimal, this goes in science, natural science, chemistry, organic chemistry, we, these are already way too many decisions. Like imagine if you had to do that every time. Nightmare. Whereas in Ce Castine, because it‚Äôs bottom up, you clip it straight to, let‚Äôs say benzene, and you put the note right under there, you don‚Äôt have to go all the way down through whatever hierarchy you‚Äôve got.

You just go straight to the, to the edge. Uh, and I think this achieves the same sort of goal because you‚Äôre not thinking, well, when am I snoozing this to? And that question is actually very complex and requires knowledge of your calendar or at least thinking of your calendar. No good at all. So,

Robin: I mean, so, so you see what I find interesting here is that you are talking about Ze Carsten, is a system for ideas and,

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: and talking about task management, and we seem to sort of naturally fallen into an idea that they‚Äôre the same thing, which I had not considered before.

That they could be the same thing really.

Tristram: They, they, they, they aren‚Äôt, but they‚Äôre very related. They‚Äôre related. The reason I‚Äôm conflating them is because we‚Äôre talking about the input, the inbox, the fleeting notes, and, and that is, that is unified in my system. And in fact, I would recommend that anyone who is building a second brain or a PKM system for themselves only have one inbox.

Doesn‚Äôt matter whether those are fleeting thoughts or tasks to do, your inbox must be just one place because two places is one too many already. This is a very old idea from, from David Allen‚Äôs GTD book. The, uh, the, the grandfather of this inbox idea is that if you have two inboxes, let‚Äôs say your email, ancient ancient history.

Ancient history, the like before YouTube, therefore it‚Äôs very old. The, if you have two inboxes, your eyes can only look at one at once, which means you cannot fundamentally trust what your eyes are telling you. If your eyes are saying, oh, my inbox empty, but I‚Äôve got this other inbox here, lemme just check that, oh, that‚Äôs empty too, but maybe I‚Äôve got a new thing in the first inbox, you it, you‚Äôve got this subtle like subconscious unease that actually maybe you‚Äôre supposed to be doing something.

So one inbox genius idea. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm unifying these two.

Robin: Yes, except it, that almost makes it more interesting. Are you saying that notes Zettelkasten are tasks or not? Because if you

Tristram: No, no. Fleet. Fleet?

Robin: you have a Zettelkasten inbox and you have a no.

Tristram: No, no. Just, just fleeting notes are just strings. Strings of text. Those strings of text have to be interpreted by, uh, by Tris tomorrow, and then he will decide whether or not to make a task in my task management system or to write up something else or, or what have you. It‚Äôs,

Robin: so they are the same

Tristram: it‚Äôs not up to me.

Robin: thing.

Tristram: Yes. The inbox is unified.

Robin: one inbox, which has a list of notes, and a note

Tristram: Mm-hmm.

Robin: a task or it may be a thought, a idea.

Tristram: The reason I‚Äôm pushing back against this is I, I deliberately don‚Äôt decide at this point whether or not it is a tasker of thought

Robin: but so it‚Äôs, so, it‚Äôs so, it‚Äôs quite, so I suppose, I think you are saying that they are the same thing in every, like as far, just about as far as I could possibly imagine they might be, if you see what I mean. Um, which I like. I mean, it‚Äôs a nice, uh, it‚Äôs a nice idea. Um, the, the, the bit where I‚Äôm gonna

Tristram: tasks start off as ideas, right.

Robin: the bit where I‚Äôm gonna fall down is that you say the place

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: are gonna, where you bring these things back up to your future self is in their morning routine of, of, um, going through the inbox.

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: Um, but that [00:45:00] doesn‚Äôt mean, you know, I mean, I do have an inbox. I do go through it every now and then, so I‚Äôm, I‚Äôm, I‚Äôm not gonna

Tristram: I don‚Äôt think you should go through the inbox. I think you should set up this, the space repetition system to go through this inbox for you.

Robin: system for you, the point where you read the things that have been brought back up by our space repetition, uh, repetition system is

Tristram: Yeah.

Robin: down and looking through the list of things that your space recognition, uh, repetition system is bringing up.

Tristram: Right. That doesn‚Äôt happen for you.

Robin: Uh, I have. Yes. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever had a routine like, you know, just about managed to brush my teeth daily. Um,

Tristram: Yeah.

Robin: but my wake up and sleep times don‚Äôt tend to be regular. And I, yes. So I don‚Äôt think I can ever say that I‚Äôve had like a string of as much as like a week or two weeks where I have at roughly the same time every day sat down and done roughly the same task, per se, apart from standup at work, which you don‚Äôt really have, have any choice. Um,

Tristram: Mm-hmm.

Robin: yeah, so I mean, I, I, I don‚Äôt think, obviously, you know, you can‚Äôt solve all the problems with, of my life with one system. Um, and as I say, I

Tristram: I mean,

Robin: I

Tristram: maybe.

Robin: and I do still manage to live as a, as an adult. Um, just about, so I. this wouldn‚Äôt be worse. Right. Um, but

Tristram: No, indeed. No indeed. I, I

Robin: than I am,

Tristram: only, only recently, Robin, only recently, like in 2020 before Lost Terminal, I had no morning routine. Like as you say, I like, I, I, I like cleaned my teeth and I probably had breakfast at some point because my body was hungry. But like the start of this was my, my first habit, which was I‚Äôve got to write lost terminal before work.

If I don‚Äôt write it before work, I‚Äôll work. I‚Äôll be too tired after work. So it must happen before work, therefore it must, must, must happen. It‚Äôs like you taking the, your, your kids to to school. Like it can‚Äôt not happen. It‚Äôs the, it absolutely must happen. And I, my baby lost terminal had had the same scheduling problem that it, these things had to happen every day.

So I was actually forced into that. And then after a few, after like a year, I had this morning routine of like sitting down and writing and then I could like hang things off it. You know, you just need that one thing, you know, that first little habit.

Robin: the, but the interesting thing there is you described Lost Terminal as your baby, uh, with, with an implication that that‚Äôs part of how you managed to do it, which is, which is very insightful. I mean, you know, you‚Äôre absolutely right that the most routine things that I do successfully are my children‚Äôs routine because they need

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: and I know that and I care about them. And it‚Äôs that caring that I‚Äôm really sort of curious about because I also feel like, you know, my life has, is, is, is improving significantly recently. Um, and it

Tristram: Great.

Robin: in taking charge of it. Which is a version of caring. It‚Äôs like caring about myself. It‚Äôs like I‚Äôm taking the time to think what is it that I really care about?

And, and so that makes a

Tristram: Mm-hmm.

Robin: difference. So, so, so really it just needs the, something to trigger me into believing this routine supports my core values. Right? Like, like that‚Äôs

Tristram: Hmm.

Robin: and then I would do it. Right. So, so it‚Äôs not, probably not as far as, as we‚Äôre saying. So anyway, I really like the system.

Um, I, I am curious, I don‚Äôt think you should maybe go into it further now ‚Äôcause we, this will get long, but I‚Äôm, I‚Äôm

Tristram: Yes.

Robin: how you configure your, um, scheduled something, whatever you call it, that system

Tristram: Yes, the, the space repetition system. Well, you and I can talk offline about it, and the listener will eventually be able to watch my video on it.

Robin: that‚Äôs pretty cool. Oh, yes. Well, so will I, so maybe, maybe I can just, if, if we don‚Äôt manage to follow up on it, I can just watch a video and then I‚Äôll know.

Tristram: It‚Äôs perfect.

item.title: On Writing & Mental Health
item.author: Namtao Productions
item.description:
Tris and Robin introduce themselves and share tips for writing podcasts, blogs, videos and how to survive inside a creative brain.

üìñ CHAPTERS

  • 00:00:00 Introductions
  • 00:01:27 Why are we here & defining ‚Äúdecapsulate‚Äù
  • 00:05:04 Podcasts are great!
  • 00:11:15 From Podcasting to blogging
  • 00:16:20 Wait, what is this podcast all about?
  • 00:24:40 Blogging II: Electric boogaloo
  • 00:38:40 Writing distractions
  • 00:53:40 Bottom-up thinking
  • 01:08:00 Decapsulate upload schedule discussion
  • 01:13:30 Conclusion

üîó LINKS

Ours

  • https://robinwinslow.uk
  • https://noboilerplate.org
  • https://lostterminal.com
  • https://modemprometheus.com
  • https://phosphenecatalogue.com

External

  • https://www.relay.fm/cortex
  • https://www.youtube.com/@CGPGrey
  • https://www.nightvalepresents.com/startwiththis
  • https://pluralistic.net/

üßë CREDITS

Decapsulate is a NAMTAO Production (namtao.com)

It is hosted by:

  • Tristram Oaten (https://mastodon.social/@0atman)
  • Robin Winslow (https://union.place/@nottrobin)

This work is BrainMade (https://brainmade.org)

Transcript

[00:00:00] Teaser 1[00:00:00] Introductions

Tris: I guess I‚Äôll go first. Hi folks, my name is Tris. I‚Äôm a podcaster and video producer, I‚Äôm a musician. In fact, I started out doing anything creative or in public by being a musician. My first career was as a web developer, and I did production on the side for 15 years, but in 2022 I accidentally became entirely self employed thanks to the surprising success of my YouTube channel, No Boilerplate. I am here with my friend Robin. Hi Robin.

Robin: Hi

Tris: Tell the listeners about yourself.

Robin: I‚Äôm Tris‚Äôs friend

I‚Äôm nowhere near as impressive in my output as Tris. I am a father. I‚Äôve always wanted to be a father and I‚Äôm very proud of, being a father to my children. I‚Äôm a big fan of openness and transparency and open source. I‚Äôve been a web developer and team leader for about 18 years. I worked for Canonical for 10 years, I worked with what is now our mutual friend, and that‚Äôs how I got introduced to Tris, and then Tris got me a job at Canonical, we worked together there for a bit, and you know, we‚Äôve known each other ever since,

I have a lot of thoughts about how to solve technical problems, as well as, How to solve other problems, and I‚Äôm a little bit obsessed with politics.

[00:01:10] Why are we here & defining decapsulate

Tris: we are here because I love talking about tech. I especially love talking about tech with you, and there are some parts of my, video audio creation writer world that I‚Äôd love for other people to get a little insight into.

And I found that speaking with. You is a great foil occasionally, although that is a backhanded compliment. But certainly you‚Äôre very good at asking difficult questions that I appreciate you asking. ‚Äú Appreciate‚Äú in, like, scare quotes.

Robin: I feel like I do sort of challenge you in a way that I, I‚Äôm surprised you‚Äôre okay with. I often feel a bit bad about it

afterwards.

Tris: You‚Äôre right. That‚Äôs probably the perfect interviewer, or, host attitude.

Robin: I feel like your interpretation of

decapsulate was different than mine. When you

first said it, I thought it sounded like a great name. And,

Tris: Oh no.

Robin: no, no, no. I think it‚Äôs good. I think this was

interesting.

It was interesting that you related it more to software

than I did,

Tris: Yes, because encapsulation means bringing everything inside an interface of some sort and bringing along the things you

need inside that

to work, maybe through internal data and internal functions or something like

that. How did you interpret it?

Robin: Well, I think, I suppose I think that decapsulate is maybe a synonym for unpack

Tris: I really like that word unpack.

Robin: I do think that it was, it‚Äôd be very interesting to talk about why we identify with unpacking things.

Because I think we do, I think lately I‚Äôve started to feel more

like I‚Äôve noticed more that people around me are not as interested

in getting to the details, talking about the details of stuff as I am. I have to be aware of that because particularly in work, there‚Äôs a lot of things where I‚Äôm like, if we were to think seriously about this problem, then we would define the basis of what we‚Äôre trying to achieve.

And then we would work out what flows from there. I always want to delve into the fine details of designing the solution clearly in a way that other people, are often quite frustrated by.

The thing that people don‚Äôt seem that interested in is more like the focus. I tend to want to look at things from many angles. I think that you aren‚Äôt, you haven‚Äôt really discovered the truth until you‚Äôve looked at it from many angles. And I think also, discovering the truth is really important. A lot of people aren‚Äôt necessarily on the same page as me in all those ways.

They aren‚Äôt necessarily interested in the truth. seeing things from a few angles and making sure they‚Äôve found the truth at the heart of it. Do you know what I mean?

Tris: Yes, it‚Äôs one of the reasons I really like talking with you, wise people are full of doubt and fools are so certain, and you‚Äôre really uncertain you‚Äôre not persuaded as easily as I am of something, there‚Äôll be many cases where I will state something I know you agree with.

I‚Äôll state an opinion or state some facts about the internet or technology or society or whatever and I will state it in a way that is not buttoned up and watertight and you will disagree with me and argue with me, which is confusing for me, well it was until I got used to it, and we‚Äôll

Go round a little bit and I‚Äôll be very, very confused because you‚Äôll be arguing Against

something I thought you really believed in and I might eventually say don‚Äôt you agree with me and you say yes I do but not the way you said it like you did not present a good argument

Robin: This isn‚Äôt a very charitable presentation.

Tris: No, it is this is how I would like to be this is a very aspirational way of doing things Annoying perhaps but when we‚Äôre talking about important topics It‚Äôs important to have the facts right and the take right? You can‚Äôt just say something that is too simple or oversimplified. Um, and this is because you are trying to find the truth, which makes you a great podcast host.

Robin: well, we‚Äôll see, see

[00:04:47] Podcasts are great

Tris: podcasts, I think, are my favorite thing. To write and to produce because audio is such a personal medium. I just want to do more and more, which is why we‚Äôre here today. Thank you, Robin, for enabling my addiction.

Robin: Is this the first podcast where you‚Äôre

talking as you,

Tris: it is. And I‚Äôm terrified because I‚Äôm usually no good without a script.

Robin: I think you‚Äôre doing fantastically well, you know, your voice is crisp and polished and your explanations are fluid. I think you‚Äôre going to, listen back to it and discover that you absolutely don‚Äôt need a

script. This is my favorite form of podcast and I found it quite interesting because I remember, the party we had on Saturday, your birthday.

So happy birthday again.

Tris: Thank you so much. I am 38, if you can believe it.

Robin: Your friend, who I won‚Äôt name because they haven‚Äôt agreed to it, said, are you planning on doing any podcasts or something like that to you? And because they. Understand a podcast to be what I also understand a podcast to be, which is people talking, usually a conversation, nonfiction,

but when I backed her up in saying this was also my understanding of podcasts somebody corrected me and said, the very oldest podcasts weren‚Äôt that at all. The very oldest podcasts were. More like works of fiction ongoing serial dramas and stuff like

that. Which I realized,

Tris: am not sure that either, point is correct. I think podcasts have always been just like books, fiction and nonfiction.

Robin: right. Quite possibly there presumably was a first podcast. It would be quite

interesting to know what that was.

Tris: It would be. I‚Äôve never even thought about that.

Robin: typey, typey, typey,

Tris: typey, sounds of, uh, mechanical keyboard clicking,

Robin: Oh yeah, your keyboard I don‚Äôt have a keyboard like yours. This is why you have a keyboard like yours

Tris: interesting.

It looks like the first podcast came on tape and was a 1989, radio program distributed on cassettes. That does feel like how, podcasts are distributed, except we‚Äôve got MP3s nowadays.

Robin: Yeah. Wow.

Oh, that‚Äôs really cool.

Tris: prefer podcasts, not just because I‚Äôm a kind of an audio person. I started out my creative career. So to speak was that I‚Äôve always loved music and so audio is very natural for me two years ago my astonishing and terrifying on YouTube made me a Reluctant video producer, but the format is garbage I suppose it‚Äôs YouTube‚Äôs fault really The whole process is much less friendly much more superficial.

Robin: Is it less

empowering?

Tris: Yeah, you can‚Äôt edit what you‚Äôve uploaded. Subscribers won‚Äôt necessarily see your videos. The story of YouTube is a story of Lower and lower empowerment for the people creating and watching it.

But I will accept their money. And the enormous reach, that the platform, has given me, No complaints there, of course. It is a garbage platform, however. But I think you have to have a garbage platform to accept the benefits of a garbage platform, which is they will put your content in front of people who want to see it.

Whereas with a podcast, you‚Äôve got nothing. You‚Äôve got an RSS feed, and that‚Äôs it.

Robin: But you can have huge success with it. Obviously people have,

Tris: You certainly can. It‚Äôs much more word of mouth, which seems much nicer if you recommend a podcast to your friend That‚Äôs the only way it can work.

Robin: Yeah. I love podcasts for that reason. I think what you were saying about audio versus video is that you feel like the amount of depth of control that you get and, it‚Äôs this really rich format. And I feel like that, that also goes with the control you have in, understanding your software and being a geek that likes, likes to configure things.

And that‚Äôs also the other real strength of podcasts because they have resisted, the enshittification of all these other mediums. Podcasts are a standout success the world over. And they are not under anyone‚Äôs control.

Tris: Yeah,

Robin: And it‚Äôs quite amazing. Like in the modern world where everything is monopolized, it is really quite astonishing that

podcasts exist

Tris: Yes, it‚Äôs wonderful as our dark forces at work to stop that you‚Äôve heard of audible originals

Robin: I don‚Äôt know that I have.

Tris: It is a marketing thing that Amazon do, where they say we‚Äôve paid a huge amount of money to these celebrities and they‚Äôre making an Audible original podcast. What that means is an exclusive podcast because they want to make the walls of their ward garden higher.

Robin: Absolutely.

Tris: Same with Apple and the same with Spotify.

Spotify are the last of the game, but there are, Spotify exclusives. And they are not on any other platform.

Robin: The most famous Spotify exclusive for a while was Joe

Rogan.

But it failed. Joe Rogan published exclusively for Spotify for, I don‚Äôt know, like a year or something. And then, didn‚Äôt renew.

It wasn‚Äôt working. The interesting thing about those stories is yes, they are all trying to do it. Every one of these monopolies wants to steal podcasting and put it in a walled garden. But none of them are particularly successful. Like, I hadn‚Äôt really heard of Audible Originals.

I‚Äôm probably an anomaly. I automatically knee jerk react against using Amazon products and stuff like that. So, I‚Äôm not representative of most people, it‚Äôs clearly not succeeding in monopolizing anything,

I don‚Äôt think.

Tris: It‚Äôs wonderfully democratic. And I think we have, to shout out, Aaron Schwartz, the creator of RSS, the late and great. Aaron Schwartz for making such a, an incredible simple system that just spread like wildfire before anyone could lock it down. think the huge success of RSS really helped get ahead of these corporations.

Robin: absolutely, yeah, oh Aaron Schwartz, I‚Äôm always so sad, it‚Äôs such a generational thing, isn‚Äôt it? It really ages me. It kind of like I‚Äôm I mean ages in the sense of like you can tell my age by the fact that I‚Äôm so triggered by the name Aaron Schwartz because it was such a thing of our

generation.

Tris: Yeah,

Robin: which probably means a lot of the

listeners might not know what we‚Äôre talking

Tris: In one of my videos where I mentioned RSS, I put a half second slide with a whole bunch of texts being very angry, not super angry, but like telling people to go find out what happened and don‚Äôt forget.

the Wikipedia page for Aaron Schwartz tells you everything you need to know. A real shame,

[00:11:02] From Podcasting to Blogging

Robin: You were talking about your enthusiasm for podcasting. I think I have always had a fascination and an enthusiasm for writing,

but I‚Äôve never really managed to Properly inhabit it. I‚Äôve always been so like, something. So scared of it or something. Maybe it‚Äôs too big for me. And I‚Äôve always procrastinated So I do have a blog where I‚Äôve published, hundreds of articles, over many years, but that amounts to like a few a year and that is pathetic output. And I wouldn‚Äôt say any of them are particularly impressive works people are welcome to check it out.

I am very much looking forward to exploring. How I could engage myself with, my genuine interests having better output, a better connection between what I‚Äôd really like to say, or do, or what I‚Äôd enjoy expressing and, actually noting it down somewhere making an impact.

I think the fact that you‚Äôre so prolific at that. I really appreciate it because it‚Äôs I think if I could learn any, like a fraction of what you do, I think I would really,

it would make a big difference to

Tris: Well, It is a lot easier writing fiction than it is writing nonfiction. I think that there are some components, some building blocks of fiction and nonfiction that are, different. I write both, nonfiction videos and fiction podcasts and when I sit down to write my 400.

Words every morning for lost terminal. Those words just flow out of my fingers because I don‚Äôt have to look anything up. I‚Äôm inventing it completely whole cloth. The world is completely up to me. You know, it‚Äôs still our world, but it‚Äôs set in the future, so there are some physical constraints.

I‚Äôm able to just write things, whatever the characters say, it all comes from creative writing. Whereas when I‚Äôm writing a script for a video, there‚Äôs a lot of back and forth. There‚Äôs a lot of checking of figures, copying of code, making sure that I‚Äôm right, and getting all of the little details right.

In non fiction, that slows you down, compare Stephen King‚Äôs output to the output of somebody writing in the non fiction space.

Robin: Some people write business books incredibly fast. Don‚Äôt

they?

Tris: but

Robin: you‚Äôve got Cory Doctorow, who is worth bringing up because he‚Äôs very much in the

space around Aaron Schwartz

And also, you know, we‚Äôve referenced enshittification but he publishes new articles. Daily, basically, as far as I‚Äôm aware I feel like there is a way to do nonfiction, which is where if you tell it as a story, even though it‚Äôs nonfiction, if you can figure out how to tell a story. That doesn‚Äôt make, possibly false claims.

It only talks about, themes that you already know to be true. I think it‚Äôs possible, especially as you get older, you get more experienced and you have, you are a genuine expert in things. It is perfectly possible, to stay within the space where the truths you hold are truths.

You don‚Äôt need to spend a lot of time finding sources

for them.

Does that make

sense?
